item.description: The Democratic Senate candidate is campaigning on his faith.

media:content.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: James Talarico in New Braunfels, Texas.

item.title: What ‘Landman’ Understands About Oil
item.description: The show does far more to criticize the oil and gas industry than it does to bolster it.
item.dc:creator: Antonia Juhasz

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times

item.title: One Year of Trump. The Time to Act Is Now, While We Still Can.
item.description: The United States is broken, but not in every way.
item.dc:creator: M. Gessen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trump Backs a Potential Primary Challenger to Bill Cassidy, a G.O.P. Senator
item.description: The president urged Representative Julia Letlow of Louisiana to run against Mr. Cassidy, in a move that is likely to further complicate his relationship with Senate Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Shane Goldmacher

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator Bill Cassidy, Republican of Louisiana, has sometimes criticized President Trump and voted to convict him in his second impeachment trial.

item.title: How a Screwdriver Salesman Helped Fuel U.S. Airstrikes in Nigeria
item.description: Spotty research from a Christian activist has been used by Republican lawmakers to justify U.S. intervention in the country.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean

media:content.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Emeka Umeagbalasi, 56, at his home in Onitsha, Nigeria, last month.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Breathing New Life Into the Oboe
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 18, 2026.

item.title: Chimney Sweeps Are Making a Comeback in the U.K. as Energy Costs Climb
item.description: The centuries-old trade is enjoying something of a revival, partly driven by rising energy costs. Today’s sweeps use new tools and technology.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Josh Firkins, left, and Tom Joslin, an apprentice, sweeping a chimney last month in London.

item.title: France’s Embassy in Iraq Is a Spoil of Antisemitism, Jewish Family Charges
item.description: A Jewish family that fled Iraq generations ago rented its home to France for use as an embassy, but Paris long ago stopped paying it rent, after Iraq stripped Jews of property.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Pranav Baskar

media:content.media:credit: Lawee and Khazzam families
media:content.media:description: An aerial view of the house built by Ezra and Khedouri Lawee in the 1930s.

item.description: Chimney sweeps have adapted to survive centuries of transition.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Testa

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 18, 2026
item.description: No corrections appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 18, 2026.

item.title: Virginia’s New Governor Moves Swiftly to Overhaul State University Boards
item.description: Abigail Spanberger, a Democrat, appointed new board members at three state schools, hours after she was sworn in as Virginia’s first female governor.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul

media:content.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Gov. Abigail Spanberger of Virginia took a variety of executive actions during her first few hours in office on Saturday.

item.title: These Are the 12 States Vying to Kick Off Democrats’ 2028 Contest
item.description: There were a few surprises, and subtle regional digs, as Democratic state parties angled for early spots on the next presidential primary calendar. The New York Times reviewed their applications.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein, Lisa Lerer and Shane Goldmacher

media:content.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. campaigning in Mount Pleasant, Iowa, in 2020. Democrats in the state are hoping to keep it at the front of the party’s presidential nominating calendar.

item.title: Trump Threatens New Tariffs To Force Sale of Greenland
item.description: On Saturday morning, President Trump announced in a social media post his latest strategy to seize control of Greenland: He is slapping new tariffs on a group of European nations until they come to the negotiating table to sell Greenland.
item.dc:creator: McKinnon de Kuyper and Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump said the new tariff would increase to 25 percent on June 1 if his demands were not met.

item.title: Armed Robbers Steal At Least $110,000 Worth of Pokémon Cards
item.description: Three men stole at least $110,00 worth of Pokémon cards from a shop in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday. The thieves held customers at gun point, smashed display cases and took money from the cash register. One of the items stolen was a first-edition Charizard card worth about $15,000, according to the store’s owner.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal and Jorge Mitssunaga

item.title: ‘Sentimental Value’ Dominates the European Film Awards
item.description: The Norwegian drama collected six awards at the event, which was moved to January this year in hopes of increasing its visibility for Oscar voters.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Rogers
item.category: The Worst Person in the World (Movie)

media:content.media:credit: Christoph Soeder/DPA, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Stellan Skarsgard, left, and Renate Reinsve both won on Saturday for their performances in “Sentimental Value.”

item.title: Use Your Words
item.description: Rena Cohen’s first Sunday puzzle gives something to everyone.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Chris Jackson/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Female sheep can solve this puzzle (and their little lambs, too!).

item.title: Greenlanders Protest Trump’s Takeover Plans
item.description: Protests erupted in several Greenlandic cites and in Denmark as President Trump intensified his efforts to take control of the Arctic island.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli and Juliette Pavy

media:content.media:credit: Juliette Pavy for The New York Times

item.title: White House Warns CBS: Air Trump Interview in Full, or ‘We’ll Sue’
item.description: In previously unreported remarks, the White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told CBS News that Mr. Trump would “sue” the news outlet if it did not air an interview unedited.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, at a briefing at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Kristina Gjerde, Advocate for Ocean Biodiversity, Dies at 68
item.description: She played a key role in negotiating a landmark United Nations treaty to protect the high seas, an agreement that went into effect this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Syria Advance on Kurdish-Held Areas as Washington Urges Restraint
item.description: Government troops drew closer to Raqqa, the largest city overseen by the Kurds, raising U.S. concerns about the renewal of a wider conflict in the region.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Syrian government forces launching a rocket toward Kurdish forces near Dibsi Faraj in northern Syria on Saturday.

item.title: National Anger Spills Into Target Stores, Again
item.description: Videos of immigration officers dragging an employee out of a store near Minneapolis, the retailer’s hometown, set off renewed political debate after years of boycotts.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin, Jacey Fortin and Sheila M. Eldred

media:content.media:credit: Adam Gray/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Gregory Bovino, center, a Border Patrol official, at a Target store in St. Paul, Minn., this month. Last week, agents detained two employees at a Target in Richfield, Minn.

item.title: Shooting at Historic New Orleans Restaurant Leaves One Dead, Several Wounded
item.description: The restaurant, Dooky Chase’s, is a New Orleans fixture with deep ties to the civil rights movement. The authorities say it was not intentionally targeted.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Sims and Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:credit: Chris Granger/The Times-Picayune/The New Orleans Advocate, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Four people were shot, one fatally, at Dooky Chase’s, a restaurant in New Orleans, on Friday night.

item.title: Ni Trump ni Machado obtuvieron lo que querían con el intercambio de la medalla del Nobel
item.description: El presidente de EE. UU. tiene la medalla de María Corina Machado, pero no se le reconoce como laureado del premio. Machado no obtuvo el respaldo de Trump para convertirse en presidenta de Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: La decisión de María Corina Machado de entregar su medalla del Premio Nobel de la Paz al presidente Trump ha sido recibida con críticas encontradas en Estados Unidos y en el extranjero.

item.title: Conservative Influencer Chased From Minneapolis Streets by Counterprotesters
item.description: A protest at City Hall was organized by a conservative influencer to draw attention to a fraud scandal in the state. He was chased by counterprotesters lobbing water balloons in frigid temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Vivian Yee and Lauren McCarthy

media:content.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Conservative influencer Jake Lang was surrounded by counterprotesters in Minneapolis on Saturday.

item.title: Mamdani Appoints New Parks Commissioner to Oversee NYC Green Spaces
item.description: The mayor announced Tricia Shimamura as the city’s new parks commissioner amid broad calls for more park funding.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

media:content.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tricia Shimamura, the Parks Department’s Manhattan borough commissioner since March 2024, will now be in charge of 30,000 acres of parkland across the city’s five boroughs.

item.title: Artemis II Moon Mission: NASA Completes Giant Rocket’s Slow Ride to Launchpad
item.description: The Space Launch System and Orion capsule were transported to the launchpad before an astronaut mission that could launch as soon as Feb. 6.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times

item.title: Maduro está en Brooklyn, pero en la ‘Little Caracas’ de Madrid los exiliados siguen esperando
item.description: La mayor diáspora de venezolanos del mundo fuera de América vive en España. Muchos celebraron la captura de Nicolás Maduro y ahora se adaptan a la idea de que los aliados del régimen siguen a cargo.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, José Bautista and Finbarr O’Reilly

media:content.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The handsome Salamanca streets, a neighborhood in Madrid known as Little Caracas, and frequented by Venezuela’s wealthy, oil rich diaspora, last week.

item.title: ¿Cuba puede sobrevivir sin el petróleo de Venezuela?
item.description: El presidente Trump detuvo los envíos de petróleo venezolano a Cuba, y los expertos afirman que se avecina un desastre. El petróleo alimenta su red eléctrica y, sin suministros alternativos, el país se sumirá en una prolongada oscuridad.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles

media:content.media:credit: Norlys Perez/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Un petrolero de bandera cubana anclado cerca de la terminal de Matanzas este mes en Cuba.

item.title: Trump Announces New Tariffs on Some European Countries in Greenland Standoff
item.description: The president escalated his drive to take charge of the Danish territory, targeting Denmark and seven other European countries with a 10 percent rate.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh, Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek

media:content.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump said the new tariff would increase to 25 percent on June 1 if his demands were not met.

item.title: What’s the Thing Only Ralph Lauren Can Bring?

item.title: Joel Primack, Physicist Who Helped Explain the Cosmos, Dies at 80
item.description: A professor at the University of California, Santa Cruz, he was a key contributor to a landmark paper that laid out how the universe came to look like it does today.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Rhoda Levine, Pathbreaking Opera Director, Dies at 93
item.description: Starting out in the 1970s as a rare woman in a field dominated by men, she directed the premieres of a pair of politically charged modern classics.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X (Opera)

media:content.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Rhoda Levine in 1995 at a rehearsal for her production of Hindemith’s “Mathis Der Maler” at New York City Opera. She was acclaimed for clear, straightforward stagings of classics, rarities and new works.

item.title: 3 Policy Moves Likely to Change Health Care for Older People
item.description: Two regulatory rollbacks, along with a new A.I. experiment in Medicare, raise some worrisome questions.

item.title: Big Oil’s Complicated Calculus for Investing in Venezuela

item.title: No, Trump Can’t Cancel the Midterms
item.description: Despite how much the president talks about canceling the 2026 midterms, the columnist Jamelle Bouie explains why he can’t on this episode of “The Opinions.”

item.title: MAGA After Trump
item.description: The president’s approval rating is a misleading signal, argues the columnist David French on “The Opinions.” Without Trump on the ballot, midterm elections will expose the true strength — or weakness — of MAGA politics.

item.title: Will 2026 Be the Year Voters Pull the Emergency Brake?
item.description: The midterms will be a battle for control of Trump’s legacy.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie, Michelle Cottle, David French and Derek Arthur

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph by Busà Photography/Getty

item.description: Even more likely than an all-out invasion of Taiwan may be “gray zone” pressures, such as cutting internet cables.

item.title: Trump’s Second Term Has Ended the Conservative Era
item.description: The right’s future is all about American nationalism.

item.title: One Year In, Trump’s Attack on American Justice is Accelerating
item.description: One year into the president’s second term, America risks losing a central feature of our democracy: that we are a country ruled by laws, not by the whims of one man.
